The King was not exactly a stranger to herâ€”but he was not a stable presence in her childhood, either. Not the way his younger brother had been.

But perhaps that was an unfair comparison as no one had a more stable or greater presence in her childhood than his younger brotherâ€”Baelon Targaryen.

(No one had a greater presence in her womanhood, eitherâ€¦)

ğŸ”¥

Rhaenyra had always been close with Baelon, as he made an immediate effort to be close to her. He was charmed by her the moment they metâ€”even when she spent most of her time screaming and was not yet capable of speaking full sentences.

Blessedly, her ability for speech and all else changed a great deal as years passed, but his fondness did not. It was an everlasting sort of love that bloomed as she grew and showed no sign of wilting as she entered adulthoodâ€”as she flowered .

It was quite the opposite, reallyâ€¦

ğŸ”¥

Their relationship had always been innocentâ€”and she had never considered him to be a romantic prospect, he was â€˜justâ€™ a man who doted upon her, listened to her, and loved her.

She loved him too, of course, for it was the most natural thing in the world to do so.

How could she not love him? The thought was impossible to considerâ€”since her adoration of him was linked with nearly all of her earliest memories.

He was linked with all her best memories, too.

Because he was the best man. He was her favorite man. He was her Kepa.

She may not have considered him as an option for her husband, but she found when the topic of her marriage was broached, the thought of spending her life with any other man made her feel sick.

Especially spending her life with Aegonâ€” which it seemed nearly everyone thought to be an excellent idea. Her protests about his maturity were swiped aside, with promises that such a thing would change in time.

She did not think so.

Her complaints about his lack of interest in anything beyond â€˜having herâ€™ were shrugged off, tooâ€”apparently it was â€˜ difficultâ€™ for him to focus on anything else when he was so eager to have her as his wife. Perhaps if she paid him more attention he would not feel so hurried and their conversations would expand beyond attempts to lure her into marriage.

Gods, it made her want to scream!

She didnâ€™t.

But she did leaveâ€” fleeing from the room and pointedly ignoring the whispers about her maturity that followed behind her. She wasnâ€™t immature she simply did not want to marry him. There was a difference that her sister and her husband seemed too dense to realize.

Andâ€¦ it was infuriating.

She knew they wouldnâ€™t force her to marry him. Butâ€¦she would have to marry someone eventually, and when she did, she would have to leave her homeâ€”leave Dragonstone.

Because they would not allow her to dismiss Aegon without good reason, and her reasons were not enough. The only word that they valued were those spoken or written by a man. Until she found one suitable to wed and speak for her, she would have to suffer these attempts to match her with the man of their choosing, instead.

Wellâ€” â€˜manâ€™ seemed an overly generous description for her cousin.

She would have to suffer their attempts to match her with Aegon.

Ugh.

ğŸ”¥

It was only Baelon who listened to her worriesâ€”drying her tears and promising he would fix it.

â€œHow? If I do not marry him I will marry someone else and have to leave andâ€”I love it here, I love the dragons, I love my sister, and I love you Kepaâ€”â€

She sniffled pathetically, wondering if the whispers were rightâ€”because she felt like a child in that moment as she asked Baelon, â€œWhat solution is there?â€

ğŸ”¥

He was the solution. He made that clear when he kissed her.

And thatâ€¦ it felt like the most natural thing in the world, too.

He had played every part a man could in her lifeâ€”once, when she was a child, that had been the part of father, and now, as a woman, he had taken on the role of her husband.

ğŸ”¥

She had not seen the Kingâ€” King Aemon Targaryenâ€” since she married his brother, a â€˜spontaneousâ€™ event that occurred no more than two moons ago. Going such a length without seeing or speaking with the man was not unusual, given how rarely they were in proximity to each other.

As one might expect, his presence was required in Kingâ€™s Landing and he spent the majority of his time there, with the Red Keep serving as his primary residence.

Rhaenyra, however, had never been particularly fond of Kingâ€™s Landing and even though she could fly and make the trip in less than a day, she rarely saw a reason toâ€”after all, her sister, niece, and Kepa were all on Dragonstone. Why would she wish to be anywhere else?

Though the Kingâ€” Aemonâ€” had a fondness for the island of Dragonstone, when he wished to retreat from the city, he usually spent time on Driftmark, the Keep that his daughter and grandchildren called home.

When he did visit Dragonstone, he luxuriated in the offerings exclusive to the land and keep. The occupants were capable of travel, and he often saw them elsewhere throughout the yearâ€”but the beauty and springs of the lands could not be appreciated unless you were on Dragonstone itself.

And so, despite knowing him nearly her entire life, she did not really know himâ€” or at least, she did not know him beyond what he meant to her husband.

He meant a great deal to her husband.

His older brother was also his only living brother and the only one of his siblings remaining in Westeros. The loss of all others had made their bond even stronger, turning it into something that Rhaenyra could scarcely comprehend, much less compare to what she shared with her sister.

Because Aemon and Baelon understood each other in a way Aemma had never understood her.

Aemma loved her, but she also judged herâ€” the last few months had made that all the more clear.

Baelon claimed Aemon would never judge himâ€”or her, either, now that she was his wife. There was too much history, respect, and love between them for Aemon to doubt his decisions. They had seen each other at their best, at their worst, and everything in between.

There was no room in their relationship for concern beyond anything beyond the otherâ€™s happiness.

Still, she was nervous.

What if their marriage was an exception?

Baelon may adore her, but he adored his brother tooâ€”his opinion was important to him, if he thought badly about their match, as everyone else seemed to, thenâ€¦ what if Baelon began to think badly of their match, too?

Selfishly, she could not bring herself to give him upâ€”she simply loved him too much.

Butâ€¦she loved him too much to ruin the relationship he had with Aemon, too.

Gods, she hoped it did not come to that.

ğŸ”¥

Aemon Targaryen had never paid her much mindâ€”at least not voluntarily . This meant he had not paid her much attention at all in the past decadeâ€”ever since she grew old enough to have manners that kept her from demanding his attention, for as a girl she had a habit and sense of entitlement that led to her sitting on whatever lap she felt was worthy of her presence.

It was a brief phase, for she soon realized there was no lap better than Baelonâ€™s and then she paid little attention to Aemon, too.

He was paying attention to her now, though.

She could feel it.

It was unfamiliar in a way that made her certain that he had never looked at her like this before.

Was it because she was older now?

Or because she married his brother?

She supposed it didnâ€™t matter. But she was curious what had made her worth looking at in his eyesâ€”whether it was of her own merit or because his brother took an interest.

Either way, her hope was the sameâ€” that he would like what he saw.

(He did.)

ğŸ”¥

She was only half listening to the discussion taking place at the other end of the tableâ€”finding herself rather amused by Aemmaâ€™s attempts to encourage Daenerys into eating the mixed vegetables she had yet to touch.

Still, she was listening enough to hear the dramatic sigh of the one and only Viserys Targaryen, the sort he so kindly reserved for her.

It was a clue to the topic of their discussionâ€” the topic being her, of courseâ€” which made her focus on it just in time to hear the irksome man speak, â€œIs that the impression you really wish to make upon them? Iâ€™m not even sure the Dornish would approve of their relations.â€

Ah, yes, her name wasnâ€™t spoken but she recognized the way he spat the words.

Charming as always.

â€œWhat would they not approve of?â€ Aemon asked, sounding curious, â€œI do believe they are familiar with our practices of incest; we do not hide it well.â€

Rhaenyra looked towards Viserys, watching his cheeks turn pink as he argued his point, â€œNot thatâ€” not only thatâ€” there is the matter of her age. That she is very nearly still a child.â€

She bristled, and Baelon sighed his mouth opening to respondâ€”but Aemon interrupted first, â€œNearly a child? Odd, then, how eager you were for her to marry your son who is, if I recall, younger than her.â€

â€œItâ€™s different,â€ Viserys argued.

Aemon snorted, â€œIs it? Are the expectations of a brideâ€™s duty dictated by the age of her groom?â€

Rhaenyra bit her lip, trying to resist interjecting for it was unlikely to improve the situationâ€¦ but she couldnâ€™t resist, â€œI think the duration of such expectations might be.â€

Aemon laughed, â€œQuite right, I suppose the brideâ€™s expectations are dictated by the age of her groom,â€ he said, correcting himself and smiling at her before addressing Viserys once more.

â€œI suppose you would not know, having never visited for diplomatic reasons or otherwise, but the Dornish are rather approving of marriages based on feelings. Less so by marriages of force.â€ Aemon said, â€œSo to answer your question, Viserys, it is precisely the impression I wish to make upon them, though I do sincerely appreciate your input. Pity it is based on such a misunderstanding of both Targaryen and Dornish practices.â€

Viserys glared, â€œI had rather fine tutors on both subjects.â€

â€œI am not questioning the quality of your education, but rather the interpretation of it. Though I suppose some things must be experienced in a physical sense to be understood.â€

Rhaenyra thought the phrasing of that curiousâ€”â€œAt that point you hire a whore not a tutor, no?â€

Viserys coughed while Aemma let out an agast, â€œRhaenyra!â€ That she pointedly ignored.

â€œYou offend me, princess, in my youth I hardly needed to hire company. I had worth beyond my purse, you know.â€ Aemon said, though his lips were curled in amusement.

She nodded, trying to look apologetic, â€œOf course, I apologize, Your Majesty. Of course, you didâ€”you had your title, too.â€

He laughed, and Aemma was quick to change the topicâ€”but it could not change Rhaenyraâ€™s thoughts, which centered on the fact that Aemon had defended her. He had defended them.

What a welcome change it was to have support outside of her marriage.

Perhaps she had been worried for no reason.

( Perhaps she should have been worried for other reasonsâ€¦)

ğŸ”¥

His interruption surprised herâ€”the knock followed by the door immediately opening, the sort of forwardness she supposed was expected between brothers.

But she did not have a brother, and she had not expected him.

She was seated in front of her vanity, brushing out her damp locks at the timeâ€”though she had tried to keep her hair out of the bath, Baelon had distracted her from this goal with his fingers, and the ends had ended up drenched when she found herself slumped against the rim and gasping for breath.

But even if he had left her to bathe in peace, this would still be necessary. The humidity of the water and heat was more to blame for the brushing required, leaving it wavy and tangledâ€”a nightmare to deal with when dry, and so, no matter how tired she was, she refused to sleep before brushing, oiling, and braiding her silver tresses.

She had barely begun when Aemon invaded their roomâ€”and after the shock faded, she found herself grateful that he had not come a quarter of an hour earlier, when she was sprawled out in the tub while his brother wasâ€” no.

She swallowed, putting a stop to that memory. Now was not a time to be aroused. Not with him here, and not so soon after finding pleasure with her husband. It was shameful the frequency she found herself desiring such a thing.

Baelon was always happy to aid herâ€”happy to satisfy herâ€” but she was too embarrassed to ask as often as she would like, feeling like a harlot and biting her lip before the words could escape. A blush usually followed too, as she battled with the want she felt.

She was blushing now, ugh.

â€œ Sorry to interrupt,â€ the man said, not sounding sorry at all.

â€œIf you were truly sorry, you may have waited for an invitation,â€ Baelon said dryly, unmoving from his place by the fire. She couldnâ€™t help but smile at how closely his thoughts matched hersâ€” great mindsâ€¦

â€œI did knock,â€ Aemon said, as if that made up for his impatience and barging in before anyone opened the door for him or even responded.

â€œThe crown has spoiled you,â€ Baelon grumbled, only for Aemon to laugh, â€œJust as your place here has spoiled youâ€”you knew no privacy in Kingâ€™s Landing.â€

Aemon looked at her, and she froze, thinking he hadnâ€™t even known she was hereâ€”if he had, he wouldnâ€™t have entered the way he did, surely?

â€œExcept when he was with our sister, of course. She became a feral thing mid-fuckâ€”she bit me on one occasion when I accidentally interrupted them.â€

She blinked, surprisedâ€”she had never heard anyone other than her speak about Alyssa so candidly.

It took her a moment to consider what else he had said about the womanâ€” how did he know of her behavior mid-fuck?

Did theyâ€”?

Gods, she had never seen Baelon respond like this to anyone other than her, eitherâ€”letting out an amused snort and shaking his head, â€œâ€˜Accidentally,â€™â€ he said, voice laced with sarcasm, â€œAs if you couldnâ€™t hear from down the hall what was happening, a warning you ignored.â€

â€œPerhaps, but to be fair, you were in my room. â€

Baelon shrugged, â€œOnly because you were bragging about having the best bed, since you were the firstborn and best sonâ€”which again, circles back to the behavior of a spoiled heir.â€

â€œBetter that than behaving like a rabid dog,â€ Aemon said, sounding childish.

â€œYou really must rid yourself of your jealousy one day, brother,â€ Baelon sniped back, sounding perfectly composed despite being the younger of the two.

Rhaenyra was looking between them, baffled.

The question escaped before she could stop it, â€œWas he jealous of you or Alyssa?

Suddenly they were both looking at herâ€”and then they were both laughing at her!

She huffed, reaching for her robe, wrapping it around herself before standing and moving towards the bedâ€”feeling awkward in Baelonâ€™s room for the first time and wondering if she could easily retreat to her own. She didnâ€™t want to leaveâ€”but she just didnâ€™t want to interfere, either.

Nor did she want to be laughed at.

ğŸ”¥

If there was anyone more entitled to Baelonâ€™s company than her, it was Aemon, and awkward as she may feel, slipping behind the curtains of their bed would at least give the illusion of privacy for them both and perhaps soothe the stuffy mood.

It did not even occur to her that they wouldnâ€™t want privacyâ€” she was a delight, truly, but her sort of company differed from that of the discussion she expected them to have.

Andâ€¦her charm was dulled when she was bored and disinterested in the topic at handâ€”but if she was interested then her charm was quite absent, too, and both could be problematic in these circumstances, which made her hesitate to join them.

She was very accustomed to sharing her opinions with Baleonâ€”perhaps too comfortable. He had always been a person she associated with freedom of her mind and his rooms had quickly become a place she now associated with freedom of her flesh, too. If she was interested in the topic she could easily find herself too interestedâ€”impassioned to the point of offending given how loose her tongue was in this space.

But Baelon called to her, â€œLittle vÄ“zos?â€

She turned to look at him, yards apart but the sincerity clear in his gaze, â€œIf you wish to sleep I shall let you, of course, but if you are being shy, I would beg you to persevere and join usâ€”there is no company I prefer, you know.â€

Oh.

She appreciated the attempt to include her, trulyâ€”

She appreciated too much to deny him, even if she had reasons to decline.

She nodded, approaching the pair and taking a seat beside Baelon, who rather immediately pulled her closerâ€”not allowing her to remain in the polite posture for company, and arranging her in the sort of embrace she would have sought out if they were alone.

She blushed, as his arms curled around her and she found herself half perched on his lap. She was not ashamed to be seen in such a way, butâ€”she knew if Aemma saw her like this, she would be ashamed of her, and thatâ€¦it hurt.

On some days, knowing this encouraged her, unwilling to alter herself and her desires to appease themâ€”but now? Well, now she was in front of a man she wanted to like her. And she was in the privacy of Baelonâ€™s rooms where this posture often led to something one should never consider in company of any sort. It made her feel rather shy, just as Baelon had guessed. It was a rare thing for her to feel, and rather unwelcome.

Perhaps it would fade, if she resigned herself to the situationâ€”and so, she did, relaxing against her husband and allowing herself to enjoy the feeling of his chest behind her, while his hands lazily stroked over her waist and hips.

It was not lost on her how intently Aemon was watching, she could feel it, the heat of his gaze.

â€œLike a kitten, almost, how sweetly she curls up, hm?â€ The older man mused, only to get his brotherâ€™s laughter in response, â€œDonâ€™t let that fool youâ€”she is very sweet, but as much of a dragon as you and me.â€

She preened under the defense, appreciating being called both sweet while also having her ability to be a beast reaffirmed.

â€œShe suits you, then. If anyone deserves something sweet it is you, brother. After all that has happened, you deserve to indulge in all the dessert you can eat.â€

â€œShe is more than an indulgence,â€ Baelon said, looking down at her with a smile, â€œYou know that, my vÄ“zos.â€

My sunshine.

It was she who instigated the kiss, though it was not overly passionateâ€”it was just difficult to resist when he was so close, so handsome, so kind and meant so much to her.

â€œMm, I see, but you do indulge her, I hope.â€

Rhaenyra caught the euphemism, grumbling that he could be indulging her right now if Aemon wasnâ€™t thereâ€”

Where had the shyness gone, she wondered?

Perhaps it was because she could tell he approved?

It seemed to radiate from him, and it made her feel comfortable with being seen like this in a way she had not felt before. And that wasâ€¦ nice. Gods, it was so nice.

Maybe it made her want to show off a little, indulge in thisâ€¦

Aemon laughed, â€œSo eager, I see the dragon, nowâ€”hiding beneath all that smooth skin.â€

She bit her lip, thinking it an odd way to address herâ€”to emphasize her state of undress. It felt like flirting. But Baelon seemed unbothered, his hand continuing to stroke her bare leg while Aemonâ€™s eyes followed the path of his brotherâ€™s fingers.

They ultimately landed on the inside of her thigh, just above her kneeâ€”not so indecent, but the attention it brought to such a place in the context of Aemonâ€™s gazeâ€¦

He shook his head, looking back to her face, â€œI have scarcely seen my brother more besotted you know.â€

Baelonâ€™s hand froze, his tone one of warning, â€œAemonâ€¦â€

â€œDo not Aemon me. You are infamous for the love you lost, brother, that is a cloud that lingers over you even on the sunniest of days. A new love, no matter how bright, has not changed thatâ€”if anything, it now shades her, too. She will hear peopleâ€™s doubts based on rumors. Let her hear reassurances based on what I have witnessed and can confirm is true .â€

She looked up at Baelon, then back to his brother, unsure of what he meant.

â€œHe and Alyssa were mad for each other, truly, wild beasts that had their lips and loins locked together whenever possible. They were young and free of worries and all they needed from each other was that. But youâ€¦the way he speaks about you is a different sort of need, and he leans on you in a way he did not with our sister. I think perhaps before you, he didnâ€™t lean on anyone at all.â€

She swallowed, wondering if that was true. She was confident in his love for herâ€”it being different than what he felt for Alyssa, but still far more vast than most women could hope for. She had never wasted time comparing herself to a woman who was long deadâ€”but it felt good to know she could provide him with something new, something of her own.

â€œYou must be very special to take on such a responsibilityâ€”to be capable of inspiring such devotion while still so young.â€ He said, his tone somber.

Too somber.

Baelon was the one to lighten things, â€œGood of you to finally realize that, brother.â€

Rhaenyra couldnâ€™t help but smile, â€œHe may have the swifter dragon but it seems to be at the cost of a slower mind.â€

Aemon shook his head, though he looked amused, â€œA terrible thing to say about your King.â€

â€œA fair king would favor honesty from all his subjects,â€ she argued, and Baelon agreed, â€œAnd honestly, it did take you an age to see how special she is. It was obvious to me the moment we met.â€

Gods, she wanted to kiss him again.

Aemon sighed, â€œPerhaps, but it is obvious to me nowâ€” and, it is obviously time for me to leave . Newlywedsâ€¦â€ He grumbled.

Rhaenyra did not look upâ€”nor did she say goodbye, she just nestled closer to her husband, waiting for the sound of retreating footsteps before she sought out all she wanted from the man she married.

ğŸ”¥

â€œYou went to the springs without me?â€ Rhaenyra asked, pouting as she combed her fingers through Baelonâ€™s damp hair.

He smiled, â€œApologies, little vÄ“zos, I did not think you would feel comfortable joining Aemon and I.â€

Oh.

She supposed that was trueâ€” it should be true, at leastâ€” and he deserved to spend time alone with his brother, she could hardly be jealous of that. Butâ€” gods, last night was such a blur she had forgotten the oddity of Aemonâ€™s words, of what he had admitted seeing and the fact she had askedâ€”

â€œWas he jealous of you or Alyssa?â€

Because he had soundedâ€¦ involved with the intimacy between Alyssa and Baelon in a way that surprised her. She had heard stories of Alyssa punching her eldest brother when he attempted to kiss her, and she knew Aemonâ€™s tastes differed from the type of woman his sisterâ€” his brotherâ€™s greatest loveâ€” was.

But things could change. Violence could turn to passion. Or perhaps Aemonâ€™s tastes were for his brother?

She had heardâ€¦rumorsâ€¦he was a lusty man, and Baelon made it clear that his brother had always been. Though people did not speculate openly about the preferences of a King or if such preferences may involve both sexes, she had heard enough to be suspicious.

Surely Baelon would have said something?

But thenâ€¦she had been naive in many things when it came to intimacy between a man and woman. Perhaps he thought hearing of two men togetherâ€” of him with a manâ€” might disgust her? Maybe he feared her judgment if he had taken part in such things?

He should know betterâ€”he should know her better than that.

She would never judge him.

But then â€¦he had insisted upon the fact that Aemon would never judge them, and she had not believed him.

Insecurity was a difficult beast to silence.

â€œI would have enjoyed it all the more if you were there, little vÄ“zos,â€ Baelon muttered, breaking her thoughts and making her smile, while also giving her an opportunity to hedge, so long as she was brave enough to do soâ€¦

She had to be brave.

That was how Baelon liked her, and she had never feared speaking freely with him before.

â€œI would hope so, unless you and Aemon are closer than I first suspected.â€ Her tone was intentionally lightâ€”teasingâ€”Baelon could brush it off if there was no truth to it.

â€œMmm, if we are, it is not in that way, sweet vÄ“zos, not anymore.â€ He said, sounding unbothered by the implicationâ€” and making one of his own.

Gods, that was more than mere implication, it was practically confirmation.

She hadnâ€™t been expecting that, even if she had asked and now that she had an answer, well, she didnâ€™t know how to respond to that.

But the idea of itâ€¦ gods she was blushing again.

â€œHis curiosity towards sex was not limited to the fairer sex and I was lusty enough at the time to welcome any hand or mouth around my cock.â€ He admitted.

Gods.

â€œI am not opposed to the point of being immune to the stimulation and sensation that follows being touched in such a way, but my desire has only truly flared for the female form. Aemon made peace with that decades ago.â€

Oh.

Her mouth felt very dry, and her cheeks very pink.

Baelon cupped her jaw and tipped her head back, forcing her to meet his gaze, â€œThat was a very long time ago. My desire only flares for you now, you should know that, little vÄ“zos.â€

She swallowed, still feeling parched but managing to get out a choked, â€œI know.â€

His lip twitched into a half smile, his hands dropping from her as he moved away, â€œI should change, have fun on your flight, my vÄ“zos.â€

Flight?

She looked down at herselfâ€”the riding leathers making her original plans obvious, before he derailed them.

Right.

ğŸ”¥

She landed as soon as she saw Sunfyre attempt to join herâ€”she did not want to encourage Aegonâ€™s attempts to catch her attention, especially not now. One would think since she was married he would give up, but no.

She respected the stubborn nature of Targaryens, for she had that in spades, butâ€”in the context of Aegon it was annoying.

Viserys and Aemma both gave her looks when she returned to the Keep, clearly knowing what their son was up to and doing nothing to dissuade him.

She ignored them, though she did pause when she was out of sightâ€”hidden by the frame of the hall though able to hear them rather clearly.

â€œSuch a shame,â€ Viserys muttered, â€œShe wonâ€™t even fly with him, dare she confront the truth of how well-matched they would have been.â€

It was Aemon who spoke nextâ€”she had vaguely seen him from the corner of her eye, playing cards with Jaehaerys, though it had not fully registered in her mind until now.

â€œWhy would such a thing show the truth of them being well matched?â€ He asked, sounding curious.

â€œWell, they are both dragonriders,â€ Viserys said, as if it was obvious.

â€œI believe the man she married is also a dragonrider, unless a tragedy has befallen Vhagar that I am unaware of,â€ Aemon said dryly, and Rhaenyra could not help but smile.

â€œYou know,â€ he drawled, â€œMy father used such logic to try and force a match between me and Alyssa. It would have been dreadful. A passion for dragons and a similar birth year does not make two people well-matched for marriage. It may make them so in your mind but if it is not so in their minds then you doom them to something far worse than â€˜well.â€™â€

There was no response.

â€œYou do your son no favors by encouraging his jealousy, you do your father a disservice by disparaging his choice, and you disrespect Rhaenyra quite horribly by disregarding her choice entirely.â€

Viserys grunted, â€œI shall not respect a child making decisions such as marrying a man old enough to be her grandfather.â€

â€œYou would respect a â€˜ childâ€™ if she favored her son. You confuse disapproval with disrespect, and it makes you seem far more childish than her,â€ Aemon said, plainly, â€œYour father has always been a better man than I. If I felt such judgment towards my actions and my choice of wife in my home, wellâ€¦my wife, my home, and my actions would remain quite the same, but the source of such criticism would be forced to find shelter elsewhere.â€

She was grinning nowâ€”she had heard Baelon tell Viserys off a dozen times, but it was nice hearing someone else come to her defense, too.

Or not even to her defense, not really. He was shaming Viserys behavior as it existed, even outside of the cause for itâ€”which was, in his mind, her.

â€œI admire the softness time has formed my brother into,â€ Aemon said, â€œBut I will not allow him to be taken advantage of because of that, do you understand my meaning, Viserys?â€ His voice was still light, but there was something threatening beneath it.

â€œI will not allow his happiness to be taken away, either, not when it has been well earned by decades of sadness and it would serve you well to remember that.â€

She liked that he was defending Baelon, too, for the implications being made about him were perhaps even worse than the ones being made about her.

He was a strong man, capable of weathering the storm of his sonâ€™s opinionsâ€”just as she was confident enough to shine no matter what her sister thought.

But they did not deserve to weather anything at all or have their happiness questioned. Not by anyone. Not even Baelonâ€™s son.

Perhaps Aemonâ€™s reminder would change things for the betterâ€”and even if it didnâ€™t, well, she would still thank him for trying.

ğŸ”¥

She got her opportunity no more than an hour later, after changing into a fresh gown and returning to the communal areasâ€”in which only Aemon remained.

â€œDid you scare them all away?â€ She asked, teasing as she settled across from him.
